questions.question: What is the fundamental principle of the two-valued logic used by mathematicians as described in the text?
options: Every statement is either True or False (Law of the Excluded Middle).
Every statement can be both True and False simultaneously.
Statements can have an undefined truth value.
Logic is subjective and depends on individual interpretation.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a truth table in sentential logic?
options: To define the meaning of simple statements.
To determine the truth or falsity of a compound statement based on its components.
To prove the Law of the Excluded Middle.
To list all possible logical connectives.

questions.question: According to the text, the logical connective 'OR' (represented by ∨) is inclusive. What does this mean for its truth value?
options: It is true only when both components are true.
It is false only when both components are false.
It is true if at least one of the components is true, and false otherwise.
It is true if exactly one of the components is true.

questions.question: In the context of a logical implication 'If P, then Q', when is the implication considered false?
options: When P is true and Q is true.
When P is false and Q is false.
When P is true and Q is false.
When P is false and Q is true.
